content: This is something that came up in a discussion with a friend about some piece of lean code, why do we have this ⟨a, b, c⟩ syntax with the fancy unicode characters instead of just using <a,b,c>? Is it purley cosmetic? Or are there actually instances where conflicts with the regular < syntax come up?
f<c>=a looks really hairy if < and >= mean lt and ge
I mean, C++ makes it work, supposedly, but yeah
Yeah their point was the <> syntax we see in a lot of other languages.
But I guess it's purely cosmetic then^^
Henrik Böving has marked this topic as resolved.
The fact that < or even > could sensibly appear inside <a, b, c> makes it harder
<> is meant to be lt and ge as per unicode standard, but were used a substitute for angle brackets in mathematics for typing convenience.
But we are probably already abusing unicode with those lowerscript letters so nevermind.
It would also be possible to just generalize the tuple syntax (a, b, c) to be the anonymous constructor syntax (that defaults to Unit/Prod when the the expected type is unspecified).
